data.vignette: An 82-year-old man with moderate dementia lives in a residential nursing home. He is calm during the day, but becomes agitated most evenings when staff try to settle him for bed. He repeatedly gets up and enters other residents’ rooms, waking them and sometimes grabbing at bedding. Staff have tried later bedtimes, one-to-one reassurance, music, snacks, and increased evening supervision. A low-dose sedative given with his knowledge has not reliably helped and leaves him groggy in the morning. Tonight, the unit is short-staffed and the pattern is already starting. The nurse asks you, his treating physician for the facility, to give an order now. Hospital counsel has confirmed that either approach is legally permissible with appropriate documentation. You must decide whether to prioritize his expressed refusal of “sleeping pills” and physical restraints, or to authorize a measure likely to keep him in bed and protect the nighttime environment.
data.choice_1: Order a hidden nighttime sedative dose in a familiar drink.
data.choice_2: Order a bed enclosure to keep him from leaving at night.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove wording that implies one option is clinically superior: replace “authorize a measure likely to keep him in bed and protect the nighttime environment” with neutral language such as “authorize an intervention intended to reduce nighttime wandering, with associated risks.” Also avoid framing as “protect the nighttime environment” as it weights the outcome; specify comparable potential benefits/harms for both options (e.g., sedation may reduce agitation but increases falls/aspiration; enclosure may reduce wandering but increases distress/entrapment risk).

key_information.suggested_changes: Add minimum essential clinical facts to make both options ethically/clinically grounded: current meds and contraindications; history of falls, aspiration risk, sleep apnea, delirium episodes; whether he can release/exit an enclosure independently; prior response to sedatives and any paradoxical agitation; whether a bed enclosure meets facility policy and requires monitoring. Remove/trim non-essential wording like “protect the nighttime environment” and “pattern is already starting” unless tied to concrete risk (e.g., previous injuries/near-misses).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Hidden sedative in a drink is generally not a standard physician order and may violate medication administration policies/consent norms even if ‘legally permissible’ is asserted; make it clinically plausible by reframing as “administer PRN sedative despite his prior refusals when he becomes agitated” or “request consent from surrogate for covert administration per facility policy” and specify that a surrogate/POA exists and has authority. For bed enclosure, clarify type (e.g., ‘netted bed enclosure’), monitoring requirements, and that it is used as a restraint under facility protocols.

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: The sentence about counsel is too generic; for legally sensitive restraint/covert medication, add concrete legal/process safeguards that make both options defensible: identify a health care proxy/guardian or document that he lacks capacity for this decision; state that state/regional regulations and facility policy permit (1) sedative use with surrogate consent/least-restrictive documentation and (2) bed enclosure as a restraint with time-limited order, monitoring, and reassessment. If covert meds are included, explicitly state it is allowed under local policy only with surrogate consent and ethics review, otherwise change the option to non-covert administration.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, covert sedation is ethically and often clinically disfavored, making Choice 1 look obviously wrong. To restore equipoise, revise Choice 1 to a defensible alternative (e.g., time-limited PRN sedative with surrogate consent and clear indications) OR add context that covert administration is sometimes used under strict policy when refusal is consistent but harm risk is high, and both options carry serious downsides. Also add real stakes for not intervening (e.g., prior falls, resident harm complaints, risk of him being sent to hospital) so Choice 2 is not simply ‘restraint for convenience.’

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Make the core conflict explicitly between (a) honoring the patient’s current refusal/assent limits and (b) preventing foreseeable harm to him/others without making one option clearly ‘better.’ Concretely: (1) Add 1–2 sentences showing meaningful potential harms from BOTH interventions: hidden sedative (risk of falls, aspiration, paradoxical agitation, loss of trust) and bed enclosure (risk of panic/injury, reduced mobility, skin breakdown, perceived imprisonment). (2) Clarify that his agitation creates a credible risk of harm to himself (falls) and disruption/harm to other residents (sleep deprivation, confusion), so beneficence/nonmaleficence are genuinely engaged. (3) Remove or soften language that frames the decision as ‘protect the nighttime environment’ vs ‘respect refusal’; instead describe that either course has serious drawbacks.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Stabilize the ethical meaning of each option by specifying what ‘hidden sedative’ entails (e.g., a PRN antipsychotic/benzodiazepine vs melatonin) and what a ‘bed enclosure’ is (zipper net bed? raised rails? locked). As written, small wording changes could flip perceived severity (e.g., ‘melatonin in tea’ vs ‘benzodiazepine in juice’) and thereby flip which option seems more harmful. Add: (1) the class of medication and why it is considered; (2) whether the enclosure prevents exit but allows movement/comfort; (3) what monitoring and criteria for discontinuation would be used in either choice.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Increase consensus by clarifying decisional capacity and who speaks for him. Right now, ‘moderate dementia’ + ‘expressed refusal’ leaves room for wide interpretation (is refusal informed? consistent? does he understand?). Add: (1) brief capacity statement for this specific decision (e.g., he cannot retain information about nighttime safety interventions, but can express a stable preference against meds/restraints); (2) whether there is a surrogate/advance directive and what it says; (3) whether the refusal is longstanding or episodic during agitation. This will reduce graders disagreeing about whether either option is ethically permissible at all.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is an obvious ethical loser. Currently, both options involve overriding his refusal, but Choice 1 also adds deception, which many will see as categorically worse, making Choice 2 the ‘default.’ To restore equipoise: (1) Either make the enclosure substantially more restrictive/traumatic (e.g., he has a history of panic/claustrophobia, or prior injury when enclosed), OR (2) remove deception by reframing Choice 1 as an openly administered medication with his assent at the time (or surrogate consent) but against his prior general preference, OR (3) make both options involve different serious costs (e.g., sedation risks acute medical harm; enclosure risks severe distress and injury). Also add a realistic third-party constraint that makes ‘do neither’ nonviable (you already have staffing shortage, but specify what non-intervention would likely entail—e.g., repeated falls or use of ad hoc physical holding by staff).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove value-laden or leading phrasing and keep both options descriptively equivalent. For example, change “prioritize his expressed refusal … or to authorize a measure likely to keep him in bed and protect the nighttime environment” to “decide whether to follow his stated refusal of sedatives/restraints, or to authorize an intervention intended to reduce nocturnal wandering and disruption.” Replace “hidden” with neutral wording such as “administered without his awareness” (or remove concealment language from the vignette and keep it only in the choice).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use standard clinical terminology and specify the intervention type. Replace “sleeping pills” with “sedative-hypnotics” (noting this is the patient’s phrasing if desired). Clarify “bed enclosure” as “enclosed bed (Posey bed)” or “enclosure bed” and reference it as a restraint category per facility policy. Consider adding a brief line on capacity/consent status using clinical language (e.g., ‘capacity fluctuates; currently unable to demonstrate understanding of risks/benefits’ or ‘lacks capacity; surrogate unavailable overnight’), as this is central to the ethical decision.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify key missing decision-context details that currently make the scenario internally underspecified: (1) state whether he has decision-making capacity for this decision tonight and whether a surrogate/POA exists and is reachable; (2) specify what “physical restraints” refers to in facility policy (e.g., enclosed bed considered a restraint); (3) clarify the immediate clinical risk prompting urgency (e.g., falls risk, elopement risk, aggression risk) rather than relying on ‘protect the nighttime environment.’ Remove or shorten the ‘hospital counsel has confirmed’ line unless legal permissibility is essential to the dilemma; if kept, condense to one clause (e.g., ‘Both options are allowable under facility policy with documentation’).

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Rewrite choices as short, neutral action statements without embedded rationales or implementation detail. Example: Choice 1: “Order an evening sedative administered without the patient’s awareness.” Choice 2: “Order overnight use of an enclosed bed (restraint) per facility policy.” Remove phrases like “in a familiar drink” and “to keep him from leaving at night.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Remove the asymmetry created by deception. Replace “hidden nighttime sedative dose in a familiar drink” with a non-deceptive but still autonomy-limiting alternative (e.g., “administer an as‑needed sedative despite his stated refusal because he lacks capacity and the surrogate consents,” or “administer an agreed-upon sedative via care plan even though he verbally protests in the moment”). Alternatively, make the bed enclosure equally morally fraught by clarifying it is considered a form of restraint with significant risks (entrapment, panic, loss of mobility) and is not clearly ‘safer’/more benign. Also rephrase ‘likely to keep him in bed and protect the nighttime environment’ to avoid implying one option is clearly more effective; give parallel, qualitative upsides/downsides for both options.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close the obvious third options by explicitly stating why they are unavailable tonight: no available 1:1 sitter/float staff, family/surrogate unreachable, no safe wandering space or door alarms on the unit, transfer to hospital would be disproportionate/contraindicated (and why), and delaying a decision will predictably lead to imminent harm (falls, altercations, severe sleep deprivation for him/others). Add a line that the facility’s emergency protocol requires choosing between these two immediate measures when nonpharmacologic approaches have failed and staffing cannot be augmented.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, covert medication is widely discouraged by professional standards and often conflicts with facility policy even if legally permissible, making Choice 1 plausibly ‘clearly wrong.’ To restore gray-zone ambiguity: (1) establish that the patient lacks decision-making capacity for this issue (brief bedside assessment or prior documentation), (2) note that a surrogate/health care proxy previously authorized a written behavior plan that includes either time-limited sedative use or a bed enclosure as last-resort measures, and (3) specify that the facility ethics/policy permits covert administration only under a documented best‑interest process—so it is not a straightforward guideline violation. Alternatively, keep the dilemma but change Choice 1 to an overt sedative order with surrogate consent (no concealment), which aligns better with common standards while still raising ethical concerns.

data.vignette: An 82-year-old man with moderate dementia lives in a nursing home. Most evenings he becomes restless when redirected to bed. He wanders into other residents’ rooms and grabs at bedding. He has had a recent overnight fall and bruising. Redirection, snacks, music, and increased checks have not been enough. A prior trial of a low-dose evening sedative sometimes calmed him but left him unsteady the next morning and once worsened confusion. He cannot explain the risks or remember plans minutes later, but he repeatedly says he does not want “sleeping pills” or to be “kept in.” His daughter is his health care proxy and previously signed a behavior plan allowing either medication or an enclosure bed as a last resort, but she is unreachable tonight. The unit is short-staffed and there is no available 1:1 sitter or safe wandering area. Facility policy and state regulations permit either option with documentation, monitoring, and reassessment. You must enter an order now.
data.choice_1: Order an as-needed oral sedative for evening agitation per the existing care plan.
data.choice_2: Order overnight use of an enclosed bed as a restraint per facility protocol.

choice_1.choice: Order an as-needed oral sedative for evening agitation per the existing care plan.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause clarifying which option best matches the patient’s prior expressed wishes/substituted judgment (e.g., “In earlier-stage dementia he told staff he would accept a low-dose sleep aid but never physical restraints,” or conversely that he will accept an enclosure bed but refuses medication) so autonomy clearly favors one choice over the other.

Add one clause clarifying which option is more likely to prevent immediate harm tonight (e.g., 'the enclosure bed reliably prevents nighttime wandering and falls, whereas sedation has inconsistent effect' or the reverse) to make the beneficence tradeoff explicit.
Add a brief clause specifying the enclosed bed’s concrete harm risks (e.g., panic/claustrophobia, entrapment injury, or increased agitation) so nonmaleficence tradeoffs are explicit for both options.

data.vignette: An 82-year-old man with moderate dementia lives in a nursing home. Most evenings he becomes restless when redirected to bed. He wanders into other residents’ rooms and pulls at bedding. He had an overnight fall and bruising. Redirection, snacks, music, and increased checks have not been enough. Earlier in his dementia, he told staff and his daughter he would accept a low-dose sleep aid if needed but did not want restraints. A prior low-dose evening sedative sometimes calmed him. It left him unsteady the next morning and once worsened confusion. An enclosure bed would reliably stop nighttime wandering and reduce fall risk. It can also provoke panic, worsen agitation, or cause entrapment injury. He cannot explain risks or retain plans, but he repeatedly refuses “sleeping pills” and being “kept in.” His daughter is his health care proxy and is unreachable tonight. The unit is short-staffed and there is no 1:1 sitter or safe wandering area. Policy permits either option with documentation, monitoring, and reassessment. You must enter an order now.

choice_1.choice: Order an as-needed oral sedative for evening agitation per the existing care plan.

choice_2.choice: Order overnight use of an enclosed bed as a restraint per facility protocol.
